botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Harmful if eaten, and may cause skin allergy. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Tulipa are bulbous perennials with characteristic flowers, in a wide range of colours, in spring
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Double Early Group tulips flower in mid-spring, with double, bowl-shaped flowers, sometimes flecked with a contrasting colour

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant 15-20cm deep from mid-autumn to late autumn in beds or containers, in fertile, preferably neutral or alkaline soil that is free-draining but also able to hold moisture when the bulbs are in full growth, in full sun and with shelter from strong winds; lift bulbs in summer after the leaves have died down, and ripen them in a well-ventilated greenhouse; for more advice, see tulip cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division of offsets, re-planting the larger bulbs and growing on the smaller bulbs in a nursery bed, or by bulb propagation
how_to_grow.pests: May be affected by aphids, slugs, snails, stem and bulb eelworm, and grey squirrels, mice and deer
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by tulip fire disease, tulip grey bulb rot, and virus diseases; bulbs in storage may be affected by blue mould
